channel.title: Parsa Hugo | Personal Blog Template
channel.description: Recent content on Parsa Hugo | Personal Blog Template

item.title: Virtual Tour
item.description: ARCHER2, the UK’s National Supercomputing Service, stands as a world-class advanced computing resource for UK researchers. Powered by the HPE Cray EX supercomputing system, ARCHER2 boasts an estimated peak performance of 28 Pflop/s. With 5,848 nodes, each housing dual AMD EPYCTM 7742 64-core processors clocked at 2.25GHz, the machine contains a total of 750,080 cores. Running ARCHER2 requires specialist staff and facilities, along with a massive power supply. The system is capable of over eleven times the scientific throughput of its predecessor, ARCHER.

item.title: History of Machines
item.description: This virtual museum showcases nearly 40 years of supercomputers at EPCC, which hosts and manages ARCHER2 on behalf of UKRI, and how the technology has changed over time.

item.title: Case Studies
item.description: We have created a collection of Case Studies highlighting ARCHER2 research

item.title: ARCHER2 Hardware
item.description: Download our ARCHER2 Hardware leaflet to learn more about what is inside the cabinets.

item.title: Beautiful Binary
item.description: Download our Beautiful Binary leaflet to learn more about how computers store information and perform calcuations.

item.title: Deep Dive
item.description: Download our Deep Dive leaflet to find out about the parts that make up a Supercomputer, and why Supercomputers are super!

item.title: Sensational Switches
item.description: Download our Sensational Switches leaflet to learn more about switches, transistors, logic, sensors and more, and you can even try building your own circuits to try things out.

item.title: Postcards
item.description: We have created a collection of Postcards highlighting ARCHER2 research - all downloadable as PDF

item.title: Paper plane
item.description:
You can make our ARCHER2 paper plane.

Print off the template sheet, double sided.

item.title: Media Gallery
item.description: We have created a gallery of images and videos, many from the ARCHER2 Image and video competitions.

item.title: Wee Archie
item.description: ARCHER2 is made of 23 cabinets containing 5,848 nodes. It requires specialist staff and facilities to run, plus a massive power supply - it’s not possible to transport parts of it to science festivals and other events! For that reason, we have created Wee Archie to help teach people of all ages about Supercomputers.

item.title: How do you use a supercomputer?
item.description: Supercomputers are often made up of a large number of coupled computer cores â€“ the brains of the computer - all working together in parallel.

item.title: Parallel Sorting game
item.description: The parallel sorting game is a simple, group activity to show why parallel computers are needed. It’s very hands-on and does not require a computer or other technology to play. Players complete a sorting task in groups of various sizes, and see how the number of objects sorted changes with the size of group.

item.title: Resources
item.description: This is a comprehensive list of our resources for your own activities.

item.title: What is a supercomputer?
item.description: A supercomputer is an extremely fast computer,usually millions of times faster than a normal home computer.

item.title: Why are supercomputers important?
item.description: Supercomputers allow us to understand things that are too difficult to see or measure in real life.

item.title: About
item.description:
Hello, from the {{site.author.name}}

We are here to tell you a bit about Supercomputers and what we do with them.

item.title: Contact
item.description:
Strikes the upper surface of the impenetrable foliage of my trees, and but a few stray gleams steal into the inner sanctuary, I throw myself down among the tall grass by the trickling stream and, as I lie close to the earth, a thousand unknown plants are noticed by me.

When I hear the buzz of the little world among the stalks, and grow familiar with the countless indescribable forms of the insects and flies, then I feel the presence of the Almighty, who formed us in his own image, and the breath of that universal love which bears and sustains.
